lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/botchat.app.BotChat.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run botchat.app.BotChat.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.
// Update the title above to match the actual product name
// Describe the action and its outcome.
// A description of the expected outcome goes here
* Represents the main entry class for the BotChat Chatbot.
* Responsible for initialising the components and starting
* @param filepath path to where tasks will be loaded
* Displays Welcome message and reads users commands,
* Parses user inputs from BotChat into commands.
* Returns the index mentioned in the user input.
* Determines if input signals end of program.
* @param input the string entered by the user.
* @return true if command is bye, false otherwise.
* @param tasks the list of tasks to be changed.
* @param ui the user interface for showing the responses.
* @throws BotChatException if the command is invalid.
public static void command(String input, TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Store store) throws BotChatException {
throw new BotChatException("OH NO! todo is missing a description");
throw new BotChatException("OH NO! deadline is missing a description");
throw new BotChatException("OH NO! deadline is missing a deadline");
throw new BotChatException("OH NO! deadline is missing a deadline");
throw new BotChatException("OH NO! event is missing a description");
throw new BotChatException("OH NO! event must include a /from and /to");
throw new BotChatException("OH NO! event must include a /from and /to");
throw new BotChatException("OH NO! event is missing a from or to date/time");
Task t = new Event(description, from, to);
throw new BotChatException("OH NO! delete is missing a value");
//Throw exception when encountered with unknown command.
throw new BotChatException("OH NO! I DON'T KNOW WHAT COMMAND IT IS");
* Handles the loading and storing of the tasks to hard drive.
* Constructs a store that manages the reading
* @param filepath path to the storage file.
* Load tasks from the storage file.
* Creates the file and its parent directory if it is missing.
* @return a list of tasks read from the file.
* Saves list of tasks into the storage file.
* @param tasks the list of tasks to be stored.
* Represents a task that has a deadline.
* Constructs a task that has a description and a deadline.
* @param description the String description of a task.
* @param by the String deadline of the task, in the format yyyy-MM-dd.
* Represents a task that has a from and to date and time.
* Constructs a tasks that has a from and to date and time.
* @param description the String description of a task.
* @param from the starting date and time of a task, in yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm
* @param to the ending date and time of a task, in yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm.
public Event(String description, String from, String to) {
* Represents a general task that cannot be instantiated.
* Constructs a Task with a description.
* @param description the String description of a task.
* Converts completion of task into user interface X.
* @return string to be displayed in user interface.
* Returns a string representation of a task for storing.
* Each subclass of Task implements their own format.
* @return string representation of a task for storing.
* Constructs a Task from a string in storage.
* The data structure to store tasks.
* Constructs a empty list of tasks.
* @param tasks the list of tasks to be abstracted away.
* To get all the tasks in the tasklist
* @return a list of all the tasks
* Returns the size of the list of tasks.
* To get a task at index i.
* @param i the index of the task to retrieve.
* Add a task to the list.
* @param task the task to add to the list.
* @param i the index of the task to delete.
* Represents a task with only a description.
* Constructs a task with a description.
* @param description the String description of a task.
* Displays the welcome message on app start.
System.out.println("What can I do for you?");
* Moves the scanner to read the next line.
* @return the string in the file being read.
* Displays the tasks in the list.
System.out.println("Here are the tasks in your list:");
* Displays message indicating task that is marked complete.
* @param t the task that is marked as done
System.out.println("Nice! I've marked this task as done:");
* Displays message indicating task is marked as not completed.
* @param t the task that is marked as not completed.
System.out.println("OK, I've unmarked this task as not done yet:");
* Displays a message indicating which task is added.
* @param t the task that is added.
* @param tasks the list of tasks to add the task to.
public void displayAdd(Task t, TaskList tasks) {
System.out.println("Got it. I've added this task:");
System.out.println("Now you have " + tasks.size() + " tasks in the list.");
* Displays a message indicating which task is deleted.
* @param t the task that is deleted.
* @param tasks the list of tasks to delete from.
public void displayDelete(Task t, TaskList tasks) {
System.out.println("Now you have " + tasks.size() + " tasks in the list.");
System.out.println("Bye. Hope to see you again soon!");
* To format the date into standard formats.

public static final DateTimeFormatter OUTPUT_DATE = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM dd yyyy");
public static final DateTimeFormatter OUTPUT_DATETIME = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM dd yyyy h:mma");
